senses.de: Something that is considered more important than other matters

Tips.title: Setting Priorities
Tips.description: The word 'priority' can express the importance of doing one task before others.
Tips.example: Finishing my homework is my priority tonight.

Tips.title: Value Judgment
Tips.description: 'Priority' often implies a decision based on what's valued more.
Tips.example: In our team, clear communication is a higher priority than speed.

Tips.title: Urgency Indication
Tips.description: Using 'priority' suggests a sense of urgency or necessity for something.
Tips.example: Getting to the airport on time is our priority.

senses.de: The right to precede others in order, rank, privilege, etc.
senses.ex: The ambulance was given priority over other vehicles.

Tips.title: Rank Signifier
Tips.description: 'Priority' can indicate that one person or group is ranked above another in a specific context.
Tips.example: Members have priority seating at the event.

Tips.title: Special Entitlement
Tips.description: The term suggests having special rights or services that others might not have.

senses.de: Importance given to a process that affects the order in which processors are allocated
senses.ex: The system assigns priority to processes according to their importance.

Tips.title: Task Importance
Tips.description: In computing, 'priority' shows the level of importance given to a task by the system.
Tips.example: Priority determines which process the CPU handles first.

Tips.title: Order of Execution
Tips.description: 'Priority' in computing often deals with the sequence in which tasks are performed.
Tips.example: Priority queues ensure critical tasks are completed first.

Emphasis.wordDefinition:
Emphasis is a way of showing importance or significance. We use emphasis to put more attention on a specific thing or idea, often by stressing or repeating it.

Emphasis is used to draw attention to something specific, while priority is used to determine the order in which things need to be done.

Important.wordDefinition:
Important refers to something that holds significant value or relevance. It concerns the significance an action or person holds.

For example, health is important, education is important.

Priority refers to the task that requires immediate attention or considered most important. It concerns the actions taken on important things, and how you organize them.

In general, something can be important to you or to a project, but a priority are the immediate actions you take on important matters.

Precedence.wordDefinition:
Precedence refers to a situation where something is considered to be more important or valuable than something else based on its order or rank.

For example, in a line of people waiting to enter a concert, those who arrived first would have precedence over those who arrived later.

Precedence is applicable when there is a clear order or ranking of importance, while priority is applicable when the urgency or importance of something needs to be assessed in a more flexible manner.

Preference.wordDefinition:
Preference refers to something that we like or enjoy more than something else. For example, we might have a preference for pizza over burgers.

Preference is about what we like more, while priority is about what needs to be done first.

Primacy.wordDefinition:
Primacy refers to being first in importance, rank, or degree. For example, a country may have primacy in a certain field or a person may have primacy in a relationship.

So, basically, primacy refers to the position of being the most important, while priority refers to the act of treating something as the most important.

Both words can be applicable in different scenarios, but primacy emphasizes a position or status, while priority emphasizes an action or decision.

Significance.wordDefinition:
Significance refers to the level of importance or impact something holds in the grand scheme of things. For example, discovering a cure for cancer would have significant impact on the world.

Both words are applicable in different contexts. Priority is applicable in situations where time is a constraint and actions need to be taken quickly, while significance is applicable in situations where the impact of something is being evaluated.

Urgency.wordDefinition:
Urgency refers to how quickly a task needs to be completed. Urgent tasks are usually time-sensitive and require immediate attention.

In simpler terms, priority is about deciding which task is more important while urgency is about deciding which task needs to be done first because of a deadline or time constraint.

Both priority and urgency are important concepts when managing tasks and deciding how to allocate time and resources. Identifying the priority and urgency of a task can help you decide which tasks are most important to tackle first.

Weight.wordDefinition:
Weight typically describes the heaviness of an object or the force of something pushing down on a surface. For example, if you are lifting weights at the gym, you might use heavier weights to challenge your muscles.

Both words can be used in different contexts, but priority is more commonly associated with decision making and time management, while weight is more commonly associated with physical objects and physics.

quotes.Text: When I get up and work out, I'm working out just as much for my girls as I am for me, because I want them to see a mother who loves them dearly, who invests in them, but who also invests in herself. It's just as much about letting them know as young women that it is okay to put yourself a little higher on your priority list.
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Michelle Obama

quotes.Text: The whole world is starting to realize that it was the most unwise thing for our society to have ignored women power, to run the society with male priorities.
quotes.Title: American Artist
quotes.Name: Yoko Ono

quotes.Text: Whoever decides to dedicate their life to politics knows that earning money isn't the top priority.
quotes.Title: German Statesman
quotes.Name: Angela Merkel

quotes.Text: Wise are those who learn that the bottom line doesn't always have to be their top priority.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: William Arthur Ward

quotes.Text: My kids are my priority, then my husband, then my life, then work.
quotes.Title: English Entertainer
quotes.Name: Helen Skelton

quotes.Text: It's important to show each other your marriage is a priority.
quotes.Title: Australian Author
quotes.Name: Zoe Foster Blake

quotes.Text: Living in the light of eternity changes your priorities.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Rick Warren

quotes.Text: I believe that we should keep the truth as a priority.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Omarosa Manigault Newman

quotes.Text: My first priority is trying to protect my family.
quotes.Title: English Actor
quotes.Name: Orlando Bloom

quotes.Text: Sleep has never been a priority in my life.
quotes.Title: Australian Actor
quotes.Name: Ryan Kwanten
